Award.AwardTitle: STTR Phase I: Termite-derived enzymatic tree bio-herbicides
Award.AbstractNarration:
The broader impact/commercial potential of this Small Business Innovation Research Phase I project is a novel tree bio-herbicide to prevent sprouting of stumps and girdled trees. If successful, it would replace synthetic chemical herbicides currently used to stop stump sprouting, cull unwanted trees, prevent disease, and control invasive species in national parks and forests, managed timberlands, and along roads, railroads, pipelines, power lines, and other rights-of-way. In a termite biomimicry approach, the enzymatic mode-of-action mimics the digestive mechanisms of termites to degrade woody tissues into their natural breakdown products. This project will enhance the scientific understanding of termite digestion and apply this understanding toward developing a commercial biological alternative to the synthetic chemicals used today.

The technical objectives in this Phase I research project are to characterize termite digestive enzyme activity responses to feeding on different wood species, to develop a heterologous production microbe capable of large scale production of the most promising termite lignocellulases, to determine their synergistic effects in combinations with commercial lignocellulases, and to demonstrate the ability of these blends to degrade solid wood and prevent cambium healing. This project advances termite digestomics and seeks to commercialize research previously funded in-part by the NSF.

POR.DRECONTENT:
In Phase I, EntoBio and partners advanced the understanding of termite digestion response to a variety of woody diets and demonstrated the effects of enzyme blends designed to mimick termite digestive enzymes on a variety of trees, shrubs, and vines.

For the first outcome, termites were fed mono-diets of ash, blue spruce, red maple, hard maple, yellow pine, oak, and filter paper. Then, their guts were isolated, homogenized, and tested for activity against a variety of cellulase, hemicellulase, and accessory enzyme substrates. Overall there were no significant differences in these activities assayed across the diet treatments supporting that the normal cocktail of termite enzymes expressed under basal conditions has broad wood substrate specificity. This suggests that a single formula would be similarly effective across a broad variety of woody plant species and that future work should focus on a single formula tested on many woody plant species.

The second outcome demonstrated that a blend containing wood-digesting enzymes can cause severe leaf wilt and desiccation in as little as a few hours (depending on species and application method) and eventually defoliation. Species with results included sycamore, Tree of Heaven, mimosa, glossy buckthorn, and Chinese parasol tree. Except for sycamore, all of these are invasive species. Other invasive species are in ongoing trials. Successful application methods included stump painting, hack-and-squirt, and injection. In most cases, the enzyme blends performed as well as or better than glyphosate at inducing wilting and defoliation or, in the case of painting stumps, preventing resprouting. And, enzymes were vastly superior in tests compared with denatured enzymes or organic herbicides such as d-limonene, rosemary oil, citric acid, clove oil, and sodium lauryl sulfate. This suggests that it is the enzymes themselves that produce the effect and not merely injection or treatment with a random treatment. Treated trees will continue to be observed for resprouting and long term effects such as accelerated decomposition.

Overall, the effects of wood-digesting enzymes on woody plants are so far very encouraging and informative towards the development of environmentally-compatible bio-herbicides for woody plants, including trees, shrubs, and vines. If successful with further research, the broader impact would be of a bio-herbicide mimicking termites and composed of already naturally-occurring fungal- and termite-derived enzymes that is environmentally-friendly, fast-acting, and safe for humans, animals, and the environment. In use, it could replace toxic synthetic herbicides for woody plants in US forests, near homes and schools, and along utilities and roads. And, where toxic synthetic herbicides are refused or banned and workers must battle sprouts with repeated cutting, such as in conservation, an enzyme treatment could greatly improve the fight against invasive woody species such as kudzu, bamboo, Tree of Heaven, and bush honeysuckle.
